October 13, 1974: Fiction
CENTENNIAL, by James Michener.  (Random House, $12.50.) Dioramic historical
novel covering the land and people around Centennial, Colo.
TINKER, TAILOR, SOLDIER, SPY, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $7.95.) Thinking
man's spy story about the search for a Soviet "mole."
THE DOGS OF WAR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $7.95.) Authenticity is the
main virtue of the thriller about an African coup d'etat.
JAWS, Peter Benchley. (Doubleday, $6.95.) "Better close for winter, Caleb. Big
shark et up all the summer people."
THE WAR BETWEEN THE TATES, by Alison Lurie. (Random House, $6.95.)
Coolly detached satire of academic life in the late sixties.
THE HOUSE OF A THOUSAND LANTERNS, by Victoria Holt. (Doubleday,
$6.95.) The usual gothic folderol about a heroine in jeopardy.
WATERSHIP DOWN,  by Richard Adams. (Macmillian, $6.95.) The peerless rabbit
saga back for a holiday-season reprise.
THE SEVEN-PER-CENT SOLUTION, edited by Nicholas Meyer.  (Dutton, $6.95.)
Droll resurrection of Sherlock Holmes, in which he kicks cocaine, foils a grand plot
against world peace.
CASHELMARA, by Susan Howatch. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Generations
beget generations in this conventional historical novel.
THE RHINEMANN EXCHANGE, by Robert Ludlum. (Dial Press, $8.95.)
Entertaining espionage thriller positing a Nazi-American wartime deal.
October 13, 1974
Non-Fiction
ALL THE PRESIDENT'S MEN, by Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward. (Simon &
Schuster, $8.95; also in paper, Warner ($1.95.) Post reporters vs. the Nixon cover-
up.
THE MEMORY BOOK, by Harry Lorayne and Jerry Lucas. (Stein & Day, $7.95.)
How to remember the things you'd rather not forget.
THE WOMAN HE LOVED, by Ralph G. Martin. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.)
Gossipy retelling of the Windsors' antique passion.
ALIVE: The Story of the Andes Survivors, by Piers Paul Read. (Lippincott, $10.) A
powerful tale of survival.
YOU CAN PROFIT FROM A MONETARY CRISIS, Harry Browne. (Macmillian,
$8.95.) Investment strategies that will allegedly keep you solvent.
MORE JOY, edited by Alex Comfort. (Crown Publishers, illustrated $12.50,
nonillustrated $7.95.) More "Joy of Sex," that is.
A BRIDGE TOO FAR, by Cornelius Ryan. (Simon & Schuster, $12.50.) A
disastrous Allied action in World War II, vividly retold.
THE GULAG ARCHIPELAGO, by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. (Harper & Row,
Cloth, $12.50; paper, $1.95.) Powerful condemnation of the secret world of Soviet
prisons.
ALL THINGS BRIGHT AND BEAUTIFUL, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's Press,
$8.95.) Pleasant memoirs of a Yorkshire veterinarian.
PLAIN SPEAKING, by Merle Miller. (Putnam's, $8.95.) An "oral biography" of
Harry Truman, with some salty opinions on a variety of things.
